awd_titl_txt: New Observational Constraints on Thermonuclear Supernovae
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support an observational program to address a number of new and long-standing problems of thermonuclear supernovae. This program will involve the coordinated observation of nearby supernovae with optical and near-infrared spectrographs on 4m and 8m class telescopes at both early times (first month or so after explosion) and at late epochs (6-12 months after explosion). To complement the spectral observations, high-cadence (roughly nightly) photometric light curves of the target supernovae will also be obtained using the 2m robotic Liverpool Telescope. The analysis will make use of results from optical spectropolarimetry in an ongoing international campaign. The program will also benefit from a close relationship with theoretical and numerical work on thermonuclear supernovae being conducted at Florida State University.

The study of thermonuclear supernovae is important to a number of branches of astrophysics. These supernovae represent the end state of the evolution of certain low-mass binary star systems. They significantly affect the energy balance and chemical evolution of the interstellar medium, and are astrophysical laboratories for nuclear physics in exotic regimes. They are among the brightest events in the universe, and exhibit a homogeneity that makes them the premier tools for measuring extragalactic distances. They have played a central role in the discovery of the acceleration of the expansion of the universe and have a key role in attempts to constrain the nature of dark energy.

This project will also support ongoing efforts to build astrophysics research at Florida State University (FSU). As a part of this effort, the department has launched a new undergraduate major in Physics and Astrophysics. The undergraduate population of FSU is diverse, roughly 25% minority students, 57% women, and also containing a high proportion of first generation college students. The astrophysics group hopes to attract these students to astrophysics through a combination of strong teaching and undergraduate research opportunities, including research in this project. The physics department has a strong tradition of outreach with active programs working to provide educational materials to K-12 schools and an on-site planetarium.

por.por_cntn:
Stellar explosion play a central role in modern Astronomy and Cosmology. After some millions to billion of years, some stars end their lives with a powerful explosion within seconds. What we observe as supernovae (SNe) is the light emitted from a rapidly expanding envelope over time-scales of month to years.  SNe happen both locally and at distances  so large that it take the light to travel 10,000,000,000 years to reach us. SNe probe the present and past Universe. So called Type Ia SNe can be used as cosmic light beacons because a tight relation between brightness and the evolution of the light emitted, called light curves (LC) which led to the discovery of an accelerated Universe and a 'dark energy' which comprises some 70% of all energy in the Universe.

 Type Ia Supernovae (SNe Ia) are thermonuclear explosions of end stages of stellar evolution of low mass stars, so called white dwarfs (WDs). If the WD is member of a close stellar system,  an explosion can be triggered by accretion from the companion star leading to a WD when it approaches the Chandrasekar limit of 1.4 Mo, or the dynamical merging of two WDs leading to low mass explosions. SNeIa appear so similar because basic nuclear physics determines the WD structure, the explosion, and the  leading to 'stellar amnesia'. To first order, the outcome does not depend on details of the explosion but the apparent insensitivity hampers advances for high precision cosmology needed to decipher the nature of the dark energy and to probe for the diversity of stellar explosions.

The differences between the possible SNe Ia channels and the details of how the nuclear flame propagates through the WD leaves their imprint in the element distribution of the ejecta. In principle, the distribution can be measured by the energy distribution of photons emitted, so called spectra. Unfortunately, the velocity shift due to the rapidly expanding envelope causes to smear out the individual signatures of the elements in the light visible with the human eye.  Only beyond the visible and red light, the so called infra-red, the features are sufficiently separated in the spectra.

We studied new observational constrains by combining advanced observations in the infra-red combined with high-performance simulations. Simulations of the explosion and the emitted light is needed because, in a computer, we can change the structure of the exploding star, the details of the physics and calculate the resulting light emitted. In contrast, observations of real supernovae only provide the light and keep us guessing for the reason.

As instruments of choice, we use NSF's Gemini, one of world largest telescopes, and analyze them using  advanced radiation hydrodynamical simulations for the explosions. Simulations are needed because, in a computer, we can change the WD structure and know what we did. We showed that late-time spectra  can be effectively used to determine the central density of the WD at the time of the explosion which is tightly related to its mass. Time series of spectra can be used to probe for the size of the initial magnetic field B. This opened  up a new path to a better understanding how the nuclear burning proceeds though the exploding star. We find that many SNe Ia originate from the explosion of 1.4 solar mass WDs, and that we need magnetic fields much larger than can be produced on earth, a piece of physics previously neglected.

An important outcome of this project was the broader impact on students, STEM education and the general public.  One graduate student and several undergraduate students (UGs) have been directly involved in the project.   This award was instrumental to build up a new astrophysics group at Florida State University which, by now,  has 60 UGs persuing their masters. 5 students have finished their PhD ...
